title: 107_s3096
content: The Act is known as the "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" or the "BLAST Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The BLAST Act aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of all new firearms for sale and those in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs. The BLAST Act aims to enhance public safety by utilizing ballistics technology to assist law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes. It includes provisions for ballistics testing of new firearms and those in Federal agency custody to identify firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it incorporates ballistics testing into existing firearms enforcement programs. The definition of ballistics is also clarified as a comparative analysis of fired bullets and cartridge casings to determine the firearm from which they were discharged. The BLAST Act requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, and store records for entry into a database as specified by the Secretary of the United States Code. The BLAST Act mandates licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, create ballistics images, store records in a database specified by the Secretary, and store fired bullet and cartridge casings as per regulations. This subsection does not create civil liability except for civil penalties. The Attorney General and the Secretary are required to provide assistance. The BLAST Act requires firearm manufacturers or importers to test fire guns, create ballistics images, and store records in a specified database. The Attorney General and the Secretary must assist in acquiring ballistics equipment and recovery equipment for manufacturers and importers. No civil liability is created except for civil penalties. The Attorney General and the Secretary are required to assist firearm manufacturers and importers in acquiring ballistics equipment, personnel for database maintenance, and providing education on ballistics for firearm crime reduction. The Attorney General and the Secretary are required to assist manufacturers and importers in developing and maintaining a ballistics database, providing education on ballistics for crime reduction, coordinating with law enforcement agencies, and taking necessary steps to make ballistics testing effective. The Attorney General and the Secretary are tasked with coordinating efforts among law enforcement agencies and the firearm industry to reduce firearm-related crime and trafficking, including establishing a computer system for prompt access to ballistics records by state and local agencies. The Attorney General and the Secretary are required to establish a computer system for state and local law enforcement agencies to access ballistics records promptly. They must also promote training for ballistics examiners and submit reports annually to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees. The Attorney General and the Secretary must establish a computer system for law enforcement to access ballistics records and promote training for examiners. They are required to submit annual reports to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on the impact of this section, including the use of ballistics records in gun crime investigations. The report will include information on the number of criminal investigations, arrests, and prosecutions where access to ballistics records aided in gun crime cases, the accessibility of ballistics records across jurisdictions, and a statistical evaluation of test programs conducted under the Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act. The report will cover the prosecution of gun crimes, accessibility of ballistics records across jurisdictions, and evaluation of test programs under the Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2001 through 2004 for equipment installation and testing sites. Authorized $20,000,000 for ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and research for fiscal years 2001-2004. Mandatory ballistics testing of firearms by the Secretary and Attorney General. The amendment authorizes $20,000,000 for ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and research for fiscal years 2001-2004. It mandates ballistics testing of all firearms by the Secretary and Attorney General once certified by relevant authorities. The amendment mandates ballistics testing of new firearms once the systems are interoperable, certified by the Attorney General and Secretary of the Treasury. The Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury have interoperable ballistics systems for mandatory testing of new firearms. Section 923(m)(1) of title 18, United States Code, will take effect 5 years after the enactment of this Act, while section 923(m)(6) will be effective on the date of enactment. Privacy rights of law-abiding citizens are protected under this Act, stating that ballistics information can only be used by law enforcement if there is a reasonable belief that a crime has been committed and the information would aid in the investigation.
